docs.lead_paragraph: I WAS a red-diaper baby. Born in 1947, the year the House Un-American Activities Committee unleashed its vengeance on the film industry, I learned secrecy at my mother's knee. My parents, first-generation Russian-American Jews, remained members of the Communist Party throughout my childhood. They often talked to my sister and me about their idealistic belief in a society in which everyone happily shared wealth and power. Yet their insistence that we keep that vision to ourselves conveyed the message that people could not be trusted.
docs.abstract: Helen Lippman column on disdain for conspicuous consumption she acquired from her parents, American Communists, even though she does not share their ideology; says she has even passed it on to her daughters; drawing (M)
